title: GRANT TITLE: for advocacy and programming to improve gender data use and resourcing
subject: SUBJECT:Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
strategy: SUPPORT STRATEGY: General support; Program support
description: Data2X, an alliance housed at the U.N. Foundation, seeks to improve the quality, availability, and use of gender data in order to make a practical difference in the lives of women and girls worldwide. Data2X works with partners to improve the production and use of gender data through convening, research, advocacy, and communications. As an anchor grantee in the data substrategy of our women?s economic empowerment work, Data2X has a track record of raising awareness about the importance of gender data, identifying gender data gaps, and building partnerships to develop new methods. During this grant period, Data2X aims to enable the availability, usability, demand for, funding of, and use of gender data by governments, multilaterals, and private sector actors. Its goals include laying the groundwork for larger-scale change in key gender data production areas such as women?s economic participation, financial inclusion, and big data; deepening the field?s understanding of the current state of gender data and actions that need to be taken to drive data use; mobilizing new actors or channels for funding; and improving its own capacity to tell the gender data story and mobilize new investments in gender data. (Strategy: International Women?s Economic Empowerment)HEALTH

title: GRANT TITLE: A Data-Driven Approach to Ending Racial Inequity Through Health Policy Evaluation and Innovation
subject: SUBJECT:Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
population: POPULATION SERVED: Ethnic and racial groups
strategy: SUPPORT STRATEGY: Data and measurement systems; Network-building and collaboration; Equal access
funder_addr: New York City, NY United States
description: Ibram Kendi proposes to create two tools: a Racial Data Tracker and a Racial Policy Tracker. Kendi's team will collect data on policies, evaluate the effects of these policies, and ensure that this information is disseminated to state and federal policymakers with the power to promulgate antiracist policy. The new Racial Data Tracker will expand the team's existing COVID-19 Racial Data Tracker to include broader data on health inequities. The new database will track, visualize, and analyze racial inequities in real time, updating weekly and, at times, daily. By presenting multidisciplinary, multisector data on every policy and structural process contributing to systemic racism, it will also aid in training a new cadre of racial data scientists. The Racial Policy Tracker will support antiracist policymaking by documenting current health policies, especially key state and federal policies, and evaluating them. Kendi and team will create a centralized, longitudinal policy database for all U.S. States and territories as well as a sample of 100 communities with populations over 75,000. Through direct appeals to public health officials and examination of legislative records, meeting minutes, and spending data, they will gather information on health policy implementation to be able to: 1) measure the racially disparate impact of policy choices across key health metrics; 2) proactively support effective antiracist policymaking; and 3) assess challenges that interested policymakers face in implementing antiracist policies.

subject: SUBJECT:Telecommunications infrastructure; Telecommunications; Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general

recipient_addr: New York City, NY United States
description: This grant increase will continue to support for the integration between the Foundation Center and GuideStar, two of the philanthropic sector’s largest information platforms. Over time, both organizations have built a stable business model that provides data to millions while developing deep expertise and insight into the data. Jointly, these organizations have 16 million users, 4 billion pieces of data, 400 local partners, and 218 Internet platforms. During the previous grant period, Candid integrated its business and data systems, including the migration of 65 years worth of data, as well as its personnel. This increase will enable the grantee to continue integrating data systems and personnel. Candid is dedicated to fostering public understanding of the foundation field and nonprofit sector, respectively, by collecting, organizing, analyzing and disseminating information on foundations, corporate giving, nonprofits and related subjects.

funder_addr: New York City, NY United States
description: Womanity and FC have been in partnership since 2012. The latest initiative utilised social media in the form of a YouTube satire show to tackle gender stereotypes in the MENA region and promote conversations to deconstruct traditional narratives. The show broke all expectations by reaching 45 million people! Moreover, 90% of the those surveyed were open to share the content and engage in discussion on the topics. Through FC’s support, Womanity was able to test new approaches that led to phenomenal results with evidence of changes in attitude. The provision of unrestricted funding in this second phase will allow Womanity to focus on its vision, strategic framework and programme delivery. Their cross-cutting strategic objectives include strengthening the capacity and resilience of partners and building content and narratives that inspire transformational change. As they pursue themes that have a disproportionate impact on gender equality, their ability to take risks and test new models will ensure they continue to find success.

subject: SUBJECT:Media Content and Platforms; Media Content and Platforms, General; Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
strategy: SUPPORT STRATEGY: General support; Program support
recipient: Greater Washington Educational Telecommunications Association Inc
description: "PBS NewsHour" covers a range of issues relevant to the foundation?s grantmaking programs, which includes coverage in areas such as climate change, the environment, education, immigration, criminal justice, and access to health care. It is a credible media source that provides viewers with in-depth, responsible, and unbiased news coverage on timely issues. Such institutions are increasingly rare, particularly as the business model for journalism continues to change. During the term of this grant, "PBS NewsHour" will continue to deepen its domestic and international news coverage, prepare for the U.S. 2024 presidential elections, as well as increase its web presence and ability to partner with online media and social platforms.

title: GRANT TITLE: for general operating support
subject: SUBJECT:Media Content and Platforms; Media Content and Platforms, General; Journalism, news and information; Investigative journalism
recipient_addr: New York City, NY United States
description: ProPublica produces high-quality investigative journalism in the public interest, with an independent newsroom and leadership by some of the nation?s most distinguished editors. It investigates business and government in areas ranging from health care to the financial system, and from the environment to practices that undermine fair elections. ProPublica?s stories have won numerous awards including two Pulitzer Prizes, a Peabody Award in the radio/podcast category, and the George Polk Award for medical reporting. A renewed two-year general operating support grant from the Hewlett Foundation will support ProPublica?s continued work in an era where investigative journalism remains under significant financial threat.

population: POPULATION SERVED: Adults; Children and youth; Students
strategy: SUPPORT STRATEGY: Online media; Program support; Public engagement and education; Research and evaluation; Systems reform
description: This grant will provide support to Education Week, an Editorial Projects in Education initiative, to expand media attention and coverage around the evolving policy landscape and the intersection of the afterschool field within the education ecosystem. The data-driven initiative will bring increased awareness to out-of-school time issues as well as the impacts of afterschool and summer learning by highlighting program innovations, creative school and community-based partnerships and key supports needed to help young people thrive socially and emotionally in academic settings to recover from the impacts of the pandemic. Editorial content will be shared through a multimedia strategy including print, web, social, live forums and other platforms.

description: The Chinese government is currently the largest lender and a major investor and trading partner for a number of resource- and biodiversity-rich nations in Latin America. Given the pressing need to accurately report on the environmental, social and governance dimensions of Chinese infrastructure and energy projects in this region of concern, China Dialogue was founded in 2008 by former BBC journalists to inform readers and push the boundaries of discussion on controversial topics. This grant will enable China Dialogue to consolidate and build on its recent growth in readership and reach, and to continue with its core mission of reporting on the China-Latin America relationship and its sustainable development challenges.

title: GRANT TITLE: for support of the Center for Media Engagement's research to improve online journalism
subject: SUBJECT:Media Content and Platforms; Media Content and Platforms, General; Media access and policy; Media access and policy, general; Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
recipient: The University of Texas at Austin
description: The Center for Media Engagement, housed in the Moody College of Communication at the University of Texas at Austin, researches, develops, and tests innovations in how newsrooms can better present news in a rapidly changing digital age. The Center works to help news organizations make decisions based on business and democratic considerations that are informed by social-scientific research. The Center aims to help news audiences gain information, appreciate diverse views, and become more engaged in the political process. This grant will support new research on how news can cut across political divides, how to signal (mis)information, and how to increase understanding across news sources and newsrooms.

title: GRANT TITLE: Adamela Trust
subject: SUBJECT:Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
strategy: SUPPORT STRATEGY: Advocacy; Equal access; Public engagement and education; Publications
description: The project goal is to elevate the work of African community justice institutions in the media. To this end, the Adamela Trust will use its The Continent newspaper to publish news reporting and features on community justice work in Africa. It will publish work outside of capital cities, where injustices are rife and often invisible. The grantee proposes to do this by appointing a communities editor, who will work closely with journalists in various African countries to produce the articles. The Adamela Trust is charitable trust, based in South Africa. It is the publisher of The Continent and the Mail and Guardian newspapers.

area: PROGRAM AREA: Health Care Delivery System Reform
title: GRANT TITLE: The Pulse: Stories Exploring Race, Racism, and Health Disparities
subject: SUBJECT:Media Content and Platforms; Media Content and Platforms, General; Journalism, news and information; Investigative journalism; Constituency journalism; Advocacy journalism
population: POPULATION SERVED: Ethnic and racial groups
strategy: SUPPORT STRATEGY: Recordings and broadcasts; Equal access; Public engagement and education; Publications
funder_addr: New York City, NY United States
description: For this project, The Pulse will produce a series of stories exploring issues of race, racism and health disparities. The stories will focus not only on describing the challenges health disparities and systemic racism in health care present but also on innovative solutions to address them. In addition, The Pulsewill collaborate with 4-5 ethnic media outlets around the country to broaden the stories’ reach communities of color. Some potential partners include MLK50: Justice Through Journalism, Presson, Sahan Journal Radio Bilingue and National Latino Public Radio. The WHYY team will support these outlets as needed to tailor the stories/reporting to their audiences. The reporting team working on the pieces will include Sandra Clark, WHYY’s Vice President for News; Maiken Scott, the host of The Pulse; and a reporting fellow who will be hired with the grant funds—of note, they will hire a young journalist of color who will be mentored by Clarke and Scott and gain national broadcast reporting experience through the project. In addition, WHYY will engage with listeners and stakeholders through virtual events and social media outreach.

title: GRANT TITLE: for a project to capture lessons from Ghana data revolution
subject: SUBJECT:Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
description: Mpuntusem Foundation is a communications nongovernmental organization based in Ghana. It works with multimedia documentation, research, and advocacy on national and continental development issues. With this grant, Mpuntusem will work with the Ghana Statistical Service to use storytelling approaches to capture Ghana?s experiences using data for achieving and monitoring progress on the Sustainable Development Goals, as well as efforts to strengthen the national data ecosystem. The goal of this work is to share learning from Ghana?s extensive data ecosystem work between 2015 and 2022 to incentivize and energize young statisticians, foster continued attention to data issues among Government of Ghana agencies, help strengthen national statistical offices in the Global South, and provide practical lessons for the evidence-informed policymaking community. (Strategy: Evidence-Informed Policymaking)

description: The Fund would partner with Report for America (RFA) to increase local reporting on health equity by supporting three RFA corps members at regional outlets: The Arizona Center for Investigative Reporting, Phoenix, AZ Data-driven, investigative reporting on health disparities in Arizona's rural communities The Washington Informer, Washington, D.C. Health care in D.C.'S Black community The Charlotte Post, Charlotte, NC Health care in Charlotte's Black community RFA places a strong emphasis on racial diversity. 45 Percent of corps members are journalists of color and would prioritize placing corps members of color in these reporting roles. In addition to financial support for members' salaries, RFA recruits, matches newsrooms and corps members, and provides training and mentoring for corps members and newsrooms.

title: GRANT TITLE: Center for Michigan
subject: SUBJECT:Media Content and Platforms; Print; Journalism, news and information; Investigative journalism; Advocacy journalism
strategy: SUPPORT STRATEGY: Public engagement and education; Publications
description: The mission of Bridge Michigan, a project of the Center for Michigan, is to inform Michigan residents through fact-based, nonprofit, nonpartisan journalism that identifies and reports on critical issues important to civic life. Michigan and the Great Lakes basin are ground zero for some of the most pressing environmental issues of our time. While Michigan’s traditional newspapers have declined, Bridge Michigan and its environment watch segment are growing rapidly. With previous support, the grantee was instrumental in working with three other news organizations in launching the successful Great Lakes News Collaborative. This grant will support Bridge Michigan as a key member of the collaborative and increase awareness and understanding of the Great Lakes and drinking water issues through more in-depth journalism.

subject: SUBJECT:Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
description: The American Prospect journal connects progressive policy to viable majority politics. A core Prospect goal is to educate the broad public on the need for a regulated capitalism that looks beyond flawed and corruptible private markets to a democratically governed economy with vibrant public institutions. The Prospect, now in its 32nd year, publishes journalists who go beyond daily headlines and scholars who can write for broad audiences. It is noted for ?explainer? pieces that deeply probe how corrupted private and public systems function, and offer remedies. Besides print six times yearly, the magazine?s website publishes several original articles every day. The Prospect sponsors a young writers fellowship, and has launched the careers of many of America?s leading public affairs journalists.

description: The Health Equity core curriculum web hub will include: 1. Health Equity topic primer, glossary of key terms, and key concepts. 2. Resources including experts, key journal articles, books, and links to organizations working in this area. 4. Video, audio, and interactive elements connecting reporters to workshops, conferences, and webcasts. 5. Weekly blog. 6. Links to key data sets available for downloading. 7. Calendar of relevant future events.

description: Nonprofit Quarterly (NPQ) provides independent, research-based journalism through its quarterly magazine and daily online journal geared toward practitioner use within the nonprofit sector, with some audience representation from philanthropy and the public sector. NPQ strives to be the authoritative independent news source for matters of civil society and views an active, sometimes disruptive, civil sector as being critical to a healthy democracy. NPQ's growing audience includes nonprofits, foundations, academia, and government. NPQ also makes much of its content freely accessible online. This is a capacity building grant to develop and offer back end infrastructure as a fee for service to support grassroots media organizations.

recipient: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
description: Michigan Radio, the state’s premier public radio station, broadcasts over four stations in the Great Lakes State. The station’s Environment Report is an ongoing news segment that explores the relationship between the natural work and everyday lives of Michiganders. With prior Mott support, Michigan Radio expanded news coverage of Great Lakes and drinking water issues and became a leading member of the Great Lakes News Collaborative. With renewed support, the Environment Report will produce more original content on these topics for broadcast and digital media platforms. The University of Michigan will continue its active engagement with the Great Lakes News Collaborative, sharing content and coordinating story production.

title: GRANT TITLE: Circle of Blue
subject: SUBJECT:Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
strategy: SUPPORT STRATEGY: Advocacy; Public engagement and education
description: Circle of Blue is an online magazine covering water issues across the globe. A staff of award-winning and veteran reporters cover drinking water, Great Lakes and a range of other water issues and events. With prior Mott support, the grantee has been a founding member of the Great Lakes News Collaborative, a unique union of journalistic talent from four of the Great Lakes region’s most trusted content providers. The grantee helped raise awareness of household water debt and insecurity and the impacts of climate change on immigration within the region, among other stories. With renewed support, the grantee will continue to support and lead the collaborative and guide its team to uncover underreported and vital stories about the Great Lakes and drinking water.

description: Covid-19 - This grant will support two separate dissemination activities for the campaign: $30,000 for paid digital advertising on social media channels. Youtube is the top priority given its ability to get eyes on the video. However, KFF will also run digital advertising campaigns on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Google Display Network, and others, and some portion of these funds may be used to support those efforts as well. $20,000 For a virtual media tour featuring DR. Boyd, and potentially DR. Tuckson and Kamau Bell. This will be a series of tv and radio interviews targeting cities with the largest Black populations, major media markets such as New York and Los Angeles, national outlets such as broadcast network morning shows, and tv and radio shows aimed at Black Americans such as The Tom Joyner Morning Show.

description: The Nonprofit Quarterly provides independent, research-based journalism through its quarterly magazine and daily online journal geared toward practitioner use within the nonprofit sector, with some audience representation from philanthropy and the public sector. It strives to be the authoritative independent news source for matters of civil society and views an active, sometimes disruptive, civil sector as being critical to a healthy democracy. The publication?s growing audience includes nonprofits, foundations, academia, and government. It also makes much of its content freely accessible online. This grant will support a new initiative called the Voice Lab, which aims to help social sector leaders develop and use their voices publicly.

description: Political Research Associates is one of the leading investigative journalism organizations monitoring and reporting on global anti-gender ideology and opposition. PRA's work plays an important role in the U.S. Reproductive Health and Rights ecosystem Hewlett supports. This grant will support Political Research Associates' strategic planning process.

description: This grant will provide funding for a 60-minute workshop to be presented at the NABJ Virtual Media Institute on Health and Education on April 24, 2021 and a 90-minute workshop for the NABJ Virtual Convention and Career Fair, August 18-21, 2021. The Fund will work closely with NABJ Director of Development Joanne Wooten to determine the workshop topics, content, panelists and moderators. It is critical that journalists are informed on key health policy issues that disproportionally impact communities of color, with a focus on where the U.S. Is currently, where the U.S. Needs to go, and how specific health policies might help achieve those goals.

description: The Program on Extremism at George Washington University is a leading source of expert analysis on timely issues related to violent and nonviolent extremism. description: Iraqueer seeks to cultivate a more inclusive and democratic Iraqi society by strengthening physical and policy protections and access to social benefits and services for women and girls, LGBTIQ persons, and persons with disabilities. Iraqueer is raising broad awareness of and support for the rights of Iraqi women and girls, LGBTIQ persons, and persons with disabilities to reduce stigma, and promote social inclusion and positive societal attitudes and norms. IraQueer is monitoring, tracking, and documenting attacks on civil society organizations, women's rights activists, LGBTIQ persons and journalists in Iraq.

title: GRANT TITLE: Journalists in Aging Fellows Program - 2020
subject: SUBJECT:Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
strategy: SUPPORT STRATEGY: Network-building and collaboration; Fellowships
funder_addr: New York City, NY United States
description: The Journalists in Aging Fellows program, a partnership of the Gerontological Society of America (GSA), has been providing training for reporters who are interested in writing about issues around aging for over a decade. The program has awarded fellowships to reporters from a wide range of national and local outlets. Participants receive several days of training and a stipend and commit to publishing at least two products. In 2019 we funded this project to support a Fund?Developed panel moderated by Melinda Abrams called “eldercare4all: Gaps Reporters Should Know About in the 2020 Campaign Debate” at the GSA Annual Scientific Meeting.

description: The goal is to better involve the media in the fight against social exclusion of women due to witchcraft allegations in Burkina Faso and the resocialization of victims. It will consist of strengthening the knowledge of 30 journalists/communicators, encouraging trained journalists/communicators to periodically produce and publish audiovisual elements and press articles on the theme of social exclusion in Burkina Faso, and organizing a press caravan to provide them with material to write about the issue.

title: GRANT TITLE: General Operations
subject: SUBJECT:Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
description: The Center for Rural Strategies’ project is to build a multi-layered and diffused communications capacity that support efforts to diversify the coalfields economy and move toward a more sustainable, green, and just post-coal economy. The project includes a set of four complementary and interrelated categories of activity: 1) Launch a “deep dive” news platform that creates and distributes solutions-focused journalism. Content will explore not only the difficult economic, social, and environmental conditions of the coalfields, but identify, analyze, and critique potential economic solutions. 2) Continue to develop and refine effective messages that can be used to frame the “just transition” debate in powerful, positive, and appealing ways.

recipient: Asociacion De Periodismo De Investigacion Ojo Publ
description: Asociacin de Periodismo de Investigacin (Ojopblico) conducts journalistic research, uses technology to improve journalistic practices in Latin American newsrooms, and empowers the generation of content and knowledge as a social movement. They promote accountability on issues of justice and inequality, the equitable use of natural resources, and expose the impact of extractive industries on the lives of peasants and society. They work in alliance with other alternative digital media such as Wambra Medio Digital Comunitario (Ecuador), Mutante (Colombia), Nmada (Guatemala) and Managua Furiosa (Nicaragua), through the Red Investigativa Transfronteriza, a collective that promotes transnational research on underreported issues, such as environmental pollution, the impact of illegal mining, and the sexual exploitation of women and girls linked to the presence of extractive industries.

subject: SUBJECT:Media Content and Platforms; Media Content and Platforms, General; Media access and policy; Media access and policy, general; Journalism, news and information; Constituency journalism; Advocacy journalism
funder_addr: New York City, NY United States
recipient: Liberia Health and Rights Journalists Network
description: To expand media engagement on human rights and HIV and AIDS that counters stigma and promotes respect for human rights of key populations, including LGBT persons, people living with HIV, and sex workers in Liberia through media dialogues, training, writing of articles and producing newsletters, holding of radio talk shows, and press conferences to challenge policymakers to demonstrate political will in bringing social and economic change to people suffering stigma and discrimination. AAMIN will work with media professionals in Montserrado, Margibi and Grand Bassa counties recognizing violations based on SOGIE, sex work and HIV status as human rights challenges. AAMIN will use the grant to engage the media and increase public awareness around SRHR issues through capacity building for media professionals including student journalists in two major journalism schools to replenish the pool of journalists covering SRHR issues with sensitivity.

recipient: Kandaakiat for Women Empowerment and Development
description: CWEN will continue to implement their economic empowerment program, ‘women on the Shelf’, throughout the Investment Stage. The female entrepreneurs with whom they work will receive training in business management, value addition, branding, and access markets. Investments will be made to equip their food processing facility with outdoor solar dryer, grinders, and stainless operating tables to support these efforts. CWEN also plans to launch ‘infofood Magazine’ to increase visibility of their members' products, as well as support 3 women annually with official product certification through the Ugandan Bureau of Standards.

recipient: De Olho nos Ruralistas - Observato´rio do agronego´cio no Brasil
description: De Olho nos Ruralistas - Observatrio do agronegcio no Brasil is a journalistic observatory created in 2016 and located in So Paulo. They focus their work on producing exclusive and specialized content, using storytelling, data journalism, geo-journalism and in-depth analysis to expose the 'hidden side' of agribusiness. Our web portal is divided into four main themes: Food, Politics, Environment and Land Conflicts, with some of the most viewed articles exceeding 100 thousand views on the portal and on our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Youtube channels.

description: The request is for an Iran-American journalist and media analyst who is experiencing rape and death threats, along with doxxing and trolling of both her and her family, including her child and extended family members. The WHRD has been reporting on human rights violations in Iran and the Middle East, and the impact of US foreign policy and sanctions against Iranians, Muslims and Middle Easterners. She suspects these are coming from the Iranian government, US Dept. of State and other pro-war factions. While she has faced cyberbullying and digital threats in the past, these new threats are immediate and heightened. She has already relocated her family to another location. The funds will be used for legal fees, digital and physical security measures.

funder: Urgent Action Fund for Feminist Activism
description: This request is to support the digital security efforts of researchers who are working on in-depth research on white supremacy, misogynistic and transmisogynistic ideologies and far-right groups with these ideologies. The research group works to raise awareness around these issues through research and analysis to provide movements and activists with information and strategies to fight back. Because of the issue focus, researchers often face targeted threats online. The group proposes to support six researchers who are facing doxxing, and other forms of online threats by hiring Privacy Duck to remove personal information and to mitigate further cyberbullying. The funds will cover a group digital security package.
